f(x) = \begin{cases} \dfrac{\tan 2x}{x},\, x\neq 0 \\ a,\, x = 0 \end{cases} %text
is continuous at $x=0$ if $a = 1$ %

reason.tex:
\[\lim_{x\to 0}\dfrac{\tan x}{x} = 1\textbf{ but } \lim_{x\to 0}\dfrac{\tan 2x}{x} = 2 \] %text
Therefore, for $f(x)$ to be continuous at $x=0$, $ a = \lim_{x\to 0}f(x) = 2$.
Hence, $a = 2$ %
